values.description:
Add a spinbox next to the step button on the bottom of the main window next to the time panel. This enables users to manually step the world by the specified number of steps

Also modified the play toolbar to only display either Play or Pause button but not both

Update: style fix - moved function above variables 

Update: Changed gui design, publish world stats msg when stepping

values.description: `GAZEBO_DEPRECATED` now takes a version number. This version number indicates when deprecation began. I set all deprecation to version 1.5.
values.title: Add version to deprecated macro

summary.raw: `GAZEBO_DEPRECATED` now takes a version number. This version number indicates when deprecation began. I set all deprecation to version 1.5.
summary.html: GAZEBO_DEPRECATED now takes a version number. This version number indicates when deprecation began. I set all deprecation to version 1.5.

values.description:
Implemented Gaussian camera noise in a shader, with modifications to SDF to
allow it be controlled per-camera.

See comments in media/materials/programs/camera_noise_gaussian_fs.glsl for
an explanation of what's going on.

To add noise to a camera, put this inside the `<camera>...</camera>` block:

    <noise>
      <type>gaussian</type>
      <mean>0.0</mean>
      <stddev>0.01</stddev>
    </noise>
values.title: Add Gaussian noise to cameras, issue #608

summary.raw:
Implemented Gaussian camera noise in a shader, with modifications to SDF to
allow it be controlled per-camera.

See comments in media/materials/programs/camera_noise_gaussian_fs.glsl for
an explanation of what's going on.

To add noise to a camera, put this inside the `<camera>...</camera>` block:

    <noise>
      <type>gaussian</type>
      <mean>0.0</mean>
      <stddev>0.01</stddev>
    </noise>
summary.html:
Implemented Gaussian camera noise in a shader, with modifications to SDF to allow it be controlled per-camera.

See comments in media/materials/programs/camera_noise_gaussian_fs.glsl for an explanation of what's going on.

To add noise to a camera, put this inside the <camera>...</camera> block:

<noise>
  <type>gaussian</type>
  <mean>0.0</mean>
  <stddev>0.01</stddev>
</noise>

values.description:
Currently if a test doesn't run in Jenkins, the test result page lists it as `Results.test_ran` (see http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-ati/128/testReport/). This means you have to click on each test_ran to see what the test actually was.

This patch will use the test name instead of Results in the xml output of check_test_ran.py, so that it's easier to see which tests are failing to run. For example if the physics test fails to run, instead of `Results.test_ran`, it will be displayed as `physics.xml.test_ran`.

UPDATE: Instead of `Results.test_ran`, it will be displayed as `physics.test_ran`
values.title: Display name of tests that don't run in Jenkins

summary.raw:
Currently if a test doesn't run in Jenkins, the test result page lists it as `Results.test_ran` (see http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-ati/128/testReport/). This means you have to click on each test_ran to see what the test actually was.

This patch will use the test name instead of Results in the xml output of check_test_ran.py, so that it's easier to see which tests are failing to run. For example if the physics test fails to run, instead of `Results.test_ran`, it will be displayed as `physics.xml.test_ran`.

UPDATE: Instead of `Results.test_ran`, it will be displayed as `physics.test_ran`
summary.html:
Currently if a test doesn't run in Jenkins, the test result page lists it as Results.test_ran (see http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-ati/128/testReport/). This means you have to click on each test_ran to see what the test actually was.

This patch will use the test name instead of Results in the xml output of check_test_ran.py, so that it's easier to see which tests are failing to run. For example if the physics test fails to run, instead of Results.test_ran, it will be displayed as physics.xml.test_ran.

UPDATE: Instead of Results.test_ran, it will be displayed as physics.test_ran

values.description:
This started out as a simple implementation of wireframe rendering, and then became complicated when I started writing a test for it. The crux of the problem centered around creating multiple render contexts in the same process. I didn't quite solve this problem, but made some solid advances in that direction and fixed a few bugs along the way. 

So, there is now a MainWindow_TEST that can be used to test various aspects of the GUI main window. It's primary limitation is that the test cannot be used with a world that requires and off-screen render buffer.
values.title: Allow rendering of models in wireframe.

summary.raw:
This started out as a simple implementation of wireframe rendering, and then became complicated when I started writing a test for it. The crux of the problem centered around creating multiple render contexts in the same process. I didn't quite solve this problem, but made some solid advances in that direction and fixed a few bugs along the way. 

So, there is now a MainWindow_TEST that can be used to test various aspects of the GUI main window. It's primary limitation is that the test cannot be used with a world that requires and off-screen render buffer.
summary.html:
This started out as a simple implementation of wireframe rendering, and then became complicated when I started writing a test for it. The crux of the problem centered around creating multiple render contexts in the same process. I didn't quite solve this problem, but made some solid advances in that direction and fixed a few bugs along the way.

So, there is now a MainWindow_TEST that can be used to test various aspects of the GUI main window. It's primary limitation is that the test cannot be used with a world that requires and off-screen render buffer.

Link now publishes timestamped velocity data used by the imu sensor for calculating accelerations
Tested the imu sensor with the BDI walking controller and the robot seems to walk fine

Fix for issue #600

values.description:
This pull request configures gazebo to first check for an external version of SDF, if it's not found it will use the built-in version of SDF.

The built-in version of SDF is deprecated and will produce a whole mess of warnings.

The built-in version will be tick-tocked, with a complete removal in Gazebo 1.7/8 (depending on our release schedule).

The external version of SDF is here: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdf

Jenkins is building SDF: http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/sdf/

Documentation: http://sdformat.com/

Ubuntu package sdf-1.4.0 is being released as we speak. Nightly builds will start on Monday. 

Here is the DRCSim matching pull-request: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/166/switch-to-use-external-sdf/diff
values.title: Split out SDF

Here is the DRCSim matching pull-request: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/166/switch-to-use-external-sdf/diff

values.description:
Issue #581 was fixed by pull request #376, but subsequently broken again by other pull requests that used the deprecated boost functions shared_dynamic_cast and shared_static_cast. I've fixed these recent changes and added a cppcheck rule to protect against regressions.

I've targeted this at issue_612, but it can be re-targeted to default if that gets merged first.
values.title: Re-fix issue #581 and add a cppcheck rule to ensure future compliance

summary.raw:
Issue #581 was fixed by pull request #376, but subsequently broken again by other pull requests that used the deprecated boost functions shared_dynamic_cast and shared_static_cast. I've fixed these recent changes and added a cppcheck rule to protect against regressions.

I've targeted this at issue_612, but it can be re-targeted to default if that gets merged first.
summary.html:
Issue #581 was fixed by pull request #376, but subsequently broken again by other pull requests that used the deprecated boost functions shared_dynamic_cast and shared_static_cast. I've fixed these recent changes and added a cppcheck rule to protect against regressions.

I've targeted this at issue_612, but it can be re-targeted to default if that gets merged first.

values.description:
The idea is to avoid adding more and more physics engine specific params to the PhysicsParam enum in PhysicsEngine.hh. 

More physics engines like simbody is being integrated and putting all params in one place is not ideal.

values.description:
Basic suppor to classify tests.

I've tried to avoid the need to pass the type when declare every test so it works with following assumptions: 

* All tests compiled outside test/ directory are consider UNIT tests. This cover all _TEST files which should be, indeed, unit tests. 
* The tests under test/ directory are consider INTEGRATION tests. Some work is still needed there to finish the migration to proper places, but can be a valid starting point.

This classification will help to select which tests we want to consider for code coverage or performance. I've set up [an example](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-classify-performance-precise-amd64-gpu-nvidia/performance/?) showing performance for INTEGRATION tests first.
values.title: Initial support to classify tests

summary.raw:
Basic suppor to classify tests.

I've tried to avoid the need to pass the type when declare every test so it works with following assumptions: 

* All tests compiled outside test/ directory are consider UNIT tests. This cover all _TEST files which should be, indeed, unit tests. 
* The tests under test/ directory are consider INTEGRATION tests. Some work is still needed there to finish the migration to proper places, but can be a valid starting point.

This classification will help to select which tests we want to consider for code coverage or performance. I've set up [an example](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-classify-performance-precise-amd64-gpu-nvidia/performance/?) showing performance for INTEGRATION tests first.
summary.html:
Basic suppor to classify tests.

I've tried to avoid the need to pass the type when declare every test so it works with following assumptions:

  • All tests compiled outside test/ directory are consider UNIT tests. This cover all _TEST files which should be, indeed, unit tests.
  • The tests under test/ directory are consider INTEGRATION tests. Some work is still needed there to finish the migration to proper places, but can be a valid starting point.

This classification will help to select which tests we want to consider for code coverage or performance. I've set up an example showing performance for INTEGRATION tests first.

values.description:
Currently, the false displayed in the DRI detection test could come from not being able to run the test since tools were not available or from a false response for checking tools. It is not possible to know which one happened.

Pull request implement feedback system so this can read in an easy way.
values.title: Improving feedback about DRI detection

summary.raw:
Currently, the false displayed in the DRI detection test could come from not being able to run the test since tools were not available or from a false response for checking tools. It is not possible to know which one happened.

Pull request implement feedback system so this can read in an easy way.
summary.html:
Currently, the false displayed in the DRI detection test could come from not being able to run the test since tools were not available or from a false response for checking tools. It is not possible to know which one happened.

Pull request implement feedback system so this can read in an easy way.

values.description:
Per Eric Krotkov’s request @faller and I have been working on improving the visual textures for the VRC arenas.

These changes are split into pull-requests across three repositories, please merge at the same time:

* #!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/26/new-vrc-textures/diff

* #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/435/new-vrc-textures/diff

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/205/new-vrc-textures/diff

### Changelist: ###

* added texture to mud

* improved grass texture in manipulation and driving tasks

* added randomized texture to rubble

* changed texture sizes in heightmaps to improve resolution (also reduces increased parallax, the remaining parallax needs to be fixed by fixing heightmap or using a trimesh instead, see [gazebo issue 572](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/572/vrc-heightmap-problems))

* replaced grass texture in walking task heightmap

* added structured texture to valve, spigot, and hose coupling (color can be changed via material script) - not perfect but best we could do with the limited amount of time we have

* removed light from manipulation area in task3 to be able to see texture on objects properly

* turned off lighting for house_1 model as global lighting in driving task made it appear way too bright

* added brick texture to starting pen

* added brick wall between manipulation area and gas station

* changed initial camera view in vrc tasks to have better overview

### Pictures of new arenas:###

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task1.png

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task2_view0.png

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task2_view1.png

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task3_view0.png

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task3_view1.png

Everyone please feel free to give feedback / issue (reasonable) concerns if some change doesn’t work for your team or if you have a change yourself you want to contribute (I’ll give you write permissions to commit to the fork).

Thanks to Maurice (MIT) for collaborating and to Max (JPL) for providing feedback.

-Thomas
values.title: New VRC Textures

summary.html:
Per Eric Krotkov’s request @faller and I have been working on improving the visual textures for the VRC arenas.

These changes are split into pull-requests across three repositories, please merge at the same time:

  • #!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/26/new-vrc-textures/diff

  • #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/435/new-vrc-textures/diff

  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/205/new-vrc-textures/diff

Changelist:

  • added texture to mud

  • improved grass texture in manipulation and driving tasks

  • added randomized texture to rubble

  • changed texture sizes in heightmaps to improve resolution (also reduces increased parallax, the remaining parallax needs to be fixed by fixing heightmap or using a trimesh instead, see gazebo issue 572)

  • replaced grass texture in walking task heightmap

  • added structured texture to valve, spigot, and hose coupling (color can be changed via material script) - not perfect but best we could do with the limited amount of time we have

  • removed light from manipulation area in task3 to be able to see texture on objects properly

  • turned off lighting for house_1 model as global lighting in driving task made it appear way too bright

  • added brick texture to starting pen

  • added brick wall between manipulation area and gas station

  • changed initial camera view in vrc tasks to have better overview

Pictures of new arenas:

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task1.png

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task2_view0.png

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task2_view1.png

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task3_view0.png

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task3_view1.png

Everyone please feel free to give feedback / issue (reasonable) concerns if some change doesn’t work for your team or if you have a change yourself you want to contribute (I’ll give you write permissions to commit to the fork).

Thanks to Maurice (MIT) for collaborating and to Max (JPL) for providing feedback.

-Thomas

values.description:
This pull request introduces a new surface property: collide_without_contact. For collision elements that have this flag enabled, the collision checker will be called, but no contact forces will be applied to the body. This will be used for the MudPlugin. There is a test world (I recommend starting it paused since one of the boxes will fall through the ground) and a regression test. I'm making a parallel pull request in the sdf repository.

UPDATE:
https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdf/pull-request/2

Re-targeted to default_worldname, re-target to default after pull request #434 is merged
values.title: New surface property: collide_without_contact

This pull request introduces a new surface property: collide_without_contact. For collision elements that have this flag enabled, the collision checker will be called, but no contact forces will be applied to the body. This will be used for the MudPlugin. There is a test world (I recommend starting it paused since one of the boxes will fall through the ground) and a regression test. I'm making a parallel pull request in the sdf repository.

UPDATE: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdf/pull-request/2

Re-targeted to default_worldname, re-target to default after pull request #434 is merged

values.title: fix *ToNano() functions, with test

summary.html:
There's only one use of any of these functions, in gazebo/physics/Gripper.cc:

  this->updateRate = common::Time(0, common::Time::SecToNano(0.75));

Looks to me like the caller expected the function to work properly, and was not relying on the incorrect behavior. So I don't think that any other code needs to be changed.

values.title: similar to pull reuqest #446, fix force torque sensor for powered joints

values.description:
This is a first pass at Mud. It works by defining a model with a contact sensor and the plugin. The model should have a collision shape with collide_without_contact set to true. The plugin uses the contact sensor to detect objects and creates dynamic joints with tunable stiffness and damping.

This pull request includes some changes to ODE that allow changes to the erp and cfm values for the constrained directions of joints. This is necessary to tune the stiffness and damping.

There is an example world: sdf/worlds/mud.world

Currently the mud can only act on one link at a time. It may also act on the ground plane if placed in contact with the ground. There is room for improvement.

UPDATE:
I've added the ability to for mud to act on multiple links, but the scoped link names must be specified as sdf parameters to the plugin (see mud.world for an example).

Merged with default, fixed a bug in my ODE changes that I found while testing with Atlas.
values.title: Mud Plugin

summary.raw:
This is a first pass at Mud. It works by defining a model with a contact sensor and the plugin. The model should have a collision shape with collide_without_contact set to true. The plugin uses the contact sensor to detect objects and creates dynamic joints with tunable stiffness and damping.

This pull request includes some changes to ODE that allow changes to the erp and cfm values for the constrained directions of joints. This is necessary to tune the stiffness and damping.

There is an example world: sdf/worlds/mud.world

Currently the mud can only act on one link at a time. It may also act on the ground plane if placed in contact with the ground. There is room for improvement.

UPDATE:
I've added the ability to for mud to act on multiple links, but the scoped link names must be specified as sdf parameters to the plugin (see mud.world for an example).

Merged with default, fixed a bug in my ODE changes that I found while testing with Atlas.
summary.html:
This is a first pass at Mud. It works by defining a model with a contact sensor and the plugin. The model should have a collision shape with collide_without_contact set to true. The plugin uses the contact sensor to detect objects and creates dynamic joints with tunable stiffness and damping.

This pull request includes some changes to ODE that allow changes to the erp and cfm values for the constrained directions of joints. This is necessary to tune the stiffness and damping.

There is an example world: sdf/worlds/mud.world

Currently the mud can only act on one link at a time. It may also act on the ground plane if placed in contact with the ground. There is room for improvement.

UPDATE: I've added the ability to for mud to act on multiple links, but the scoped link names must be specified as sdf parameters to the plugin (see mud.world for an example).

Merged with default, fixed a bug in my ODE changes that I found while testing with Atlas.
